#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The Univeristy of Helsinki from file .
#Text=Image : Smaug .
#Text=Are there any ethical considerations around exposing ants to toxins and parasites ?
#Text=Legally , no .
#Text=Insects do not have any ' rights ' as such regarding ethics .
#Text=That said , we do take measures to not make them ' suffer unnecessarily ' .

#Text=For example , dissections are done when the ants are anesthetized ( either by CO2 or Ice ) , and when ants need to be killed , we do it in alcohol , which kills the ants in a matter of seconds .
#Text=So while the ants do not have ' rights ' as such , we still try to handle them with as much respect as possible ( even though the experiment involves infecting them with a deadly fungus ) .
#Text=But even though the 12,000 ants in our study sounds like a lot ( and it is ) , this is negligible in the ' grand scheme of things ' .
#Text=It has been calculated that in the Netherlands alone , nearly a trillion insects die against just the licence-plates of cars every six months .
#Text=I do n't own a car , so that means I 'm excused right ? ; )
#Text=This is the first evidence for self-medicating insects .
#Text=How widespread do you think this phenomenon could be in reality ?
#Text=It 's not actually the first evidence for self-medication in insects .
#Text=Moths and fruit flies definitely do it , and there 's evidence in honey bees and bumble-bees as well .
#Text=So it seems to be quite wide-spread in the insect world .
#Text=I have no doubt that as time goes on , there will be more and more cases documented .
#Text=Insects ( and animals in general ) seem to be quite good at taking care of themselves .
#Text=How might ants locate healing substances in the wild ?
#Text=Very good question .
#Text=This is something that 's important to know .
#Text=If they would only do it in the lab , the behaviour would n't be very interesting .
#Text=We have some guesses where they might get it from , but at the moment we do n't know yet .
#Text=That said , I plan to investigate this question ( among others ) further [ in ] the next couple of years .
#Text=Another file photo of Formica fusca , this time showing foraging workers feeding .
#Text=Image : Sedeer El-Showk .
#Text=For your PhD you researched ants ' scent-based communications .
#Text=Could healthy ants perhaps tell other ants are infected and encourage this behaviour ?
#Text=There 's not much known about this .
#Text=There 's conflicting evidence about whether sick ants actually smell different from healthy ones or not .
#Text=At the moment it seems that sick ants mostly take care of the problem themselves .
#Text=Sick ants stop most interaction with nestmates and especially brood , and leave the nest to die in isolation .
#Text=This is probably for reducing chance of infecting nestmates , but of course it also reduces the work load of their nest-mates , as their corpse does n't have to be dragged out etc.
